contentrichtext.text: {{coord|54.425|-7.096|display=title|region:GB_scale:50000}} {{NI_district | district_name = Dungannon and South Tyrone Borough Council | district_logo = | district_map = [[File:Dungannon and South Tyrone in Northern Ireland.svg|250px]] | area_rank = 5th | district_area = 315<ref>http://www.dungannon.gov.uk/pubuploads/Profile%20&%20Statistics.doc</ref> | district_HQ = [[Dungannon]] | district_iso = GB-DGN | district_ons = 95M | <!-- Fetch dynamic statistics from Template:PopLookupNI --> protestant_pc = 33% | catholic_pc = 64.1% | district_control = '''No overall control''' <br /> [[Sinn Féin]]: 8 <br /> [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]]: 6 <br /> [[Ulster Unionist Party|UUP]]: 4 <br /> [[Social Democratic and Labour Party|SDLP]]: 3 <br />[[Éirígí]]: 1 | district_MLAs = '''[[Fermanagh and South Tyrone (Assembly constituency)|Fermanagh & South Tyrone]]''' & '''[[Mid Ulster (Assembly constituency)|Mid Ulster]]''' <br /> [[Sinn Féin]]: 6 <br /> [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]]: 1 <br /> [[Social Democratic and Labour Party|SDLP]]: 1 <br /> [[Ulster Unionist Party|UUP]]: 2| district_MPs = [[Michelle Gildernew]] (Sinn Féin) <br>[[Martin McGuinness]] (Sinn Féin)| meeting_place = | web_address = http://www.dungannon.gov.uk | }} '''Dungannon and South Tyrone Borough Council''' ({{lang-ga|Comhairle Buirge Dhún Geanainn agus Thír Eoghain Theas}}, [[Ulster Scots dialects|Ulster Scots]]: ''Rathgannon an Sooth Owenslann Burgh Cooncil'')<ref>[http://www.dungannon.gov.uk/index.cfm Dungannon & South Tyrone Borough Council]</ref> is a local council in [[Northern Ireland]]. Its main town is [[Dungannon]], where the council is headquartered. The council area covers the southern part of [[County Tyrone]] (along with a small area of [[County Armagh]]) and has a population of nearly 48,000. Apart from Dungannon there are many smaller towns including: [[Augher]], [[Clogher]], [[Fivemiletown]], [[Ballygawley, County Tyrone|Ballygawley]], [[Caledon, County Tyrone|Caledon]], [[Aughnacloy, County Tyrone|Aughnacloy]], [[Benburb]], [[Moy, Northern Ireland|Moy]] and [[Coalisland]]. The district was originally named Dungannon, and took its present name on November 25, 1999, after petitioning the [[Secretary of State for the Environment]]. The Dungannon and South Tyrone Council area consists of four electoral areas: Blackwater, Clogher Valley, Dungannon Town and Torrent. In the 2005 elections, 22 members were elected from the following political parties: 8 [[Sinn Féin]], 5 [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP), 4 [[Ulster Unionist Party]] (UUP) 4 [[Social Democratic and Labour Party]] (SDLP) and 1 [[Éirígí]] (EIR). The Council adopted the [[d'Hondt method|d'Hondt]] system in 2001 which allows the position of Mayor and Deputy Mayor to be allocated according to party size. The current mayor is Councillor [[Michelle O'Neill]] (SF) and the Deputy Mayor is Councillor Norman Badger (UUP). In elections for the [[Westminster Parliament]] it is split between the [[Mid Ulster (constituency)|Mid-Ulster]] and [[Fermanagh & South Tyrone (constituency)|Fermanagh & South Tyrone]] constituencies. ==Review of Public Administration== Under the Review of Public Administration (RPA) the council is due to merge with [[Magherafelt District Council]] and [[Cookstown District Council]] in 2011 to form a single council for the enlarged area totalling 1714 km² and a population of 120, 096.<ref>{{cite web | title=Minister Foster announces decisions on Local Government Reform | work=DoE | url=http://www.doeni.gov.uk/index/local_government/minister_foster_announces_decisions_on_local_government_reform.htm | accessdate=2008-05-31}}</ref> The next election was due to take place in May 2009, but on April 25, 2008, [[Shaun Woodward]], [[Secretary of State for Northern Ireland]] announced that the scheduled 2009 district council elections were to be postponed until the introduction of the eleven new councils in 2011.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7367253.stm ''Northern Ireland elections are postponed'', BBC News, April 25, 2008, accessed April 27, 2008]</ref> ==See also== *[[Local government in Northern Ireland]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.dungannon.gov.uk/ Council Website] *[http://www.dungannonlife.com/ Dungannon Life] *[http://www.flavouroftyrone.com/ A Flavour of Tyrone] {{Northern_Ireland Local Government}} [[Category:Politics of County Tyrone]] [[Category:Dungannon]] [[Category:Local authorities of Northern Ireland]]
